title: What type of music can you play with a telecaster? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are actually several different models of Telecaster. I myself have two, an American Standard Tele, which is what I’m going to assume we’re discussing here, and an FMT-HH Tele, which is really a Telecaster in name only, because it’s so different. It has a set (glued on) neck as opposed to a bolt-on, it has a slightly arched top, and two coil-tapped humbucking pickups. I use mine mostly for playing slide. The Standard Tele looks like this:  Fixed bridge, two single-coil pickups, three position switch. This one has a rosewood fretboard, but they can also have maple necks. This is actually a very versatile guitar. I originally bought mine for those times when I want that distinctive Telecaster twang, but I’ve since found that I’ve been using it in many other situations, and been quite pleased with the result. As you probably know, rock/pop musicians like Bruce Springsteen, Keith Richards, Steve Cropper and Joe Strummer play(ed) Teles; eminent country guitarists include Albert Lee, Vince Gill, James Burton and Buck Owens; blues/rock musicians: Albert Collins, Mike Bloomfield, Jeff Beck, Roy Buchanan… the list goes on. I would not want to use a Telecaster for anything that involves high levels of distortion, like metal or heavy rock. This is in part due to the single-coil pickups, which can get pretty noisy at high volumes and high gain. It also lacks the aggressive tone that many metal players look for (which is one of the places where humbucking pickups can really shine). A Telecaster is a more nuanced sound, generally. As a footnote, I should point out that there’s a fair bit of overlap across Fender products. A bit of tinkering with the sound can get a Tele to sound a lot like a Strat, and vice versa (you can’t get the distinctive “quack” that a Strat has on the 2 and 4 switch positions, but you can get a lot of the other sounds reasonably close.) I’ve also heard players make their Mustangs and Jaguars sound a lot like Teles as well. What it really comes down to is how the guitar “works” for you, the player: whether you like its feel, its tone, its styling, its “energy”, for want of a better word. I’ve used this quote from Frank Zappa before, but it bears repeating: “If you pick up a guitar and it says, ‘Take me, I'm yours,’ then that's the one for you.” Hope this helps.

Short answer: Any style that can be played on electric guitar. Most of the really popular electric guitar designs (Tele, Strat, Les Paul, etc.) have achieved their popularity by being versatile and suitable for a wide variety of styles. The two exceptions I can think of are if you require an acoustic guitar tone (in which case you need a guitar with some kind of transducer pickup in the bridge) or ultra high-gain styles (in which case you will probably need a guitar with humbucker pickups or active pickups).

All of ‘em. Tommy Tedesco, a legendary sessions player, would show up for studio work with just a Tele. ‘But we need a jazz sound here’ (ducked behind sound barrier having reset his tone settings on amp and guitar). GREAT! Just what we wanted! ‘We need more of a rock and roll, Les Paul tone here’ (twiddle) Perfect! ‘Now, how about a bouzouki?’ (Twiddle) Just what we were looking for! ‘We’ll send a tech to help you with all your equipment…’ All with a Tele.

You can play any type of music on a Telecaster. Ed Bickett played Jazz, the Rolling Stones played Rock, Jeff Beck has played all types of music on a Tele. It is one of the most versatile guitars ever made. The tone knob is very effective at modulating the highs and lows, there are different bridges that can influence the sound. There are maple and rosewood necks and different body woods that tweak the sound. There are only 12 notes in various octaves in western music. The Tele has all 12.

Well, you can play just about any type. It’s just a guitar, like any other in that sense. However, there is a “classic” Telecaster sound that historically helped define the country sound in the 60’s and 70’s. And sometimes it gets pigeon-holed as the perfect guitar for a country act. But plenty of other Blues and Rock artists have favored the Tele as well. Everybody from Muddy Waters and Curtis Mayfield to George Harrison and Keith Richards have been big fans.

What style is it NOT good for. I have played Jazz, Rock, Blues, Country, Alternative, Progressive styles. I’ve finger picked, hybrid picked, Travis picked all styles. This guitar can do whatever you want. And I’m just talking the average run of the mill Tele, no mods, no extra pickups, no special stuff. That’s quite versatile, if you ask me. Oh, you did! :D

The Telecaster is not limited in terms of genre. It can literally do anything. In classic configuration, it excels at Funk, pop, reggae, blues, country, Punk, classic rock, soul and more. With twin humbuckers it excels at literally anything that requires distortion, up to and including djent.

A Tele is among the most versatile of guitars. Not ideal for an all-acoustic band or solo act playing Americana (folk) music, but it can be done. And classical guitar ideally is played on an instrument built for that purpose. But jazz, pop, rock, blues, and country all have rich histories with the Tele.

Pretty much everything! The Tele excels at bright, percussive, sharp and biting tones, however, with a small amount of adjustment, can be made to adapt to most any musical genre or style. I have one and have/can use it for almost anything.

One of my friends bought a George Harrison rosewood Tele several years ago. It’s become his main guitar for everything. He plays in a country band, but he has no problems playing jazz or blues on it. They do make for a pretty good hard rock guitar if you don’t mind the buzz.
Just about every possible type of music can be played on a Telecaster, although I wouldn’t recommend trying the Concerto de Aaranuez on one..
WHY NOT ASK ( WHAT MUSIC A TELECASTER ( GOOD ONE ) IS NOT GOOD FOR?? WHERE THAT MUSIC HAS A GUITAR IN IT! BASSED ON THAT… THE TERM (GOOD FOR!) WILL BE RELATIVE !
Any type of music. A Tele is my favourite guitar. I guess it’s mainly associated with country but it’s a really versatile guitar.
Pretty much any music any electric guitar can play, a Telecaster can handle. A Telecaster is a very versatile guitar.
The Tele is King of Country music but there are famous Blues, Jazz and Rock players that play it. It is Pete Townsend of the Who that has made it famous for loud Rock.
